Bro just for the sake of clarification, process does not operate on a specific port, maybe protocol that is used by process usually operates on some specific port. If you start a process and process uses let's say tcp socket on some port let's say 4000 it doesn't mean that process assigned port 4000, it means that process uses socket that operates through port 4000 and you create a lot of sockets with different ports but that wouldn't mean that port is assigned to the process. Best ever explanation of how communication between two devices happens.

Router has Routing table that holds several entries and it starts looking the destination IP address from there. If there is no match, it sends packet to configured 0.0.0.0 router that is usually ISP router to figure out from there. If there is matching entry than router changes packet destination MAC address to the MAC address of the next hop router and sends it, if there are several matchings than in its Routing table router has specific field called Metric that represents the amount of hops till destination host and chooses the best route from there. There are much more to consider but this is simplified overall of the process

But i have a question: How do routers/intermediary devices know whom to send packets that will lead to destination??? Which algorithm is used???

@abhishekmaurya9503  it's a really long story, I can't explain it from scratch but I may give you a pinch of it to make things a bit more clear.  Your PC -> ISP -> Intermediary Devices -> Destination Server things get a lot complex in intermediary devices, protocols being used in between; QUIC(google invention alternative to TCP), UDP, FTP, SSL, TLS exc. the info passing through intermediary devices have a header and tail part, they are used for routing, there are bunch of algorithms being used for that , they simply guess where the info moves next according to header + IP + bandwidth + congestion  other factors, it's a track between your public IP and the IP of website you request an answer. IP with subnet mask speaks for itself, frames can be routed according to subnet masks it's one part of whole story. Algorithm checks header+IP with subnet mask + exc. decides where to jump next. Think it as a graph data structure with nodes attained by specific IPs , it has a location protocol where a machine may guess last destination just by looking numbers I mentioned above.  I hope this made it a bit more clear for you, take care of yourself.

I think mobile data IP address is assigned by one internet service provider company, and when you try to switch your mobile data to wifi. First, the connection is interrupted and cut off. So there will be one local IP address exists in your phone, When wifi connection is connected successfully, a global IP address is then assigned to your phone. According to https://whatismyipaddress.com/keeps-changing article, it states that when your device is connecting to the Wi-Fi. It actually only borrow the IP address from the router and the IP address doesn't belong to your device. The IP address we used on our mobile phone is dynamic, so every time you link to a Wi-Fi connection, the IP address will be refreshed. This is just a simple explanation, conversation, and assumption of my own opinion. If any mistake here please let me know, and please tolerate my broken English grammar.
